ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PURPOSE OF PRIME MINISTER'S
TRIP TO IPOH AND CAMERON HIGHLANDS


    1. Dr Lee Siew Choh asked the Prime Minister what was the purpose of his latest trip to Ipoh and the Cameron Highlands.

Column: 702



    The Prime Minister: Sir, as the Member for Queenstown may have read in the newspapers, I went to Ipoh and the Cameron Highlands for a holiday.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Since there was also an A.S.A. meeting and since the Prime Minister was there, could the Prime Minister inform us whether his visit had any connection with A.S.A.?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I had the privilege to be in Cameron Highlands a few days before the Federation Prime Minister and his party arrived. For that reason my friends and I had acclimatised ourselves to the Cameron Highlands' climate and the grass there. As a consequence, we won the golf match.

ELECTRICITY SUPPLY
TO ZEHNDER ROAD IN PASIR PANJANG


    2. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Prime Minister when will electricity supply reach the people of Zehnder Road in Pasir Panjang.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, a scheme for the supply of electricity to the houses at Zehnder Road, Pasir Panjang, was considered by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee in 1961. This was the provision of electricity supply to 58 houses at an estimated cost of $37,720. The monthly revenue from these houses was estimated at $22,620 for a five-year period - in fact, amounting to a subsidy of $15,100 or $260 per house. The Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee received requests for the provision of such amenities from all over the island. As the funds available are limited, the Committee has to afford priority to schemes which it considers would benefit the greatest number at the lowest cost. This scheme was not included in the immediate programme for the provision of electricity supply to kampongs because of the small number of houses involved and the high rate of subsidy per house. It will, with all other schemes that did not get priority last year, be considered again later in the year to reassess its priority rating.

FEMALE EMPLOYEES IN
GOVERNMENT SERVICE


    3. Dr Lee Siew Choh asked the Minister for Finance (1) what is the total number of female employees in the Singapore Government Service; (ii) how many of them are monthly rated; how many are daily rated; and (iii) how many of them have benefited from the recent decision of Government to implement its policy of equal pay for equal work.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The total number of female employees in the Singapore Government service is approximately 7,275. Of these, 105 are daily-rated and the rest are monthly-rated.

    Practically everyone will benefit in one way or the other from the policy of equal treatment for women. There are a small number of women in professional grades and in certain other occupations where they already enjoy equal pay. Even they will get other benefits such as permanency of status after marriage and similar retirement benefits as men.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Would the Minister tell us how many have actually benefited to date?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Treasury circular to give effect to this proposal has been drafted and at the present moment, it is being examined by me. When it is passed, all these benefits will be made available to women employees with effect from 1st March this year.

COMMON MARKET WITH
FEDERATION
(Progress)


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether he will make a statement as to what progress has been made with regard to the achievement of a proposed Common Market with the Federation.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the two Governments have submitted a request to the United Nations to despatch a high-powered team to Malaya and Singapore.

    The Governments propose that the mission should be headed by a certain distinguished international figure who was one of the principal architects of the European Economic Community. This person, however, has found difficulty in accepting this invitation because of his other international commitments.

    The Deputy Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tun Abdul Razak, has written a personal letter to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, U Thant, requesting his intercession on behalf of the two Governments.

    Mr David Marshall: The Minister informed this House five months ago on the 17th of November of this request. Are we to understand that in fact there have been no developments in the past five months?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already indicated that this international dignitary had been approached and that there was some difficulty in arranging a suitable timetable for him to come here. Without going into details, the present position is that the Deputy Prime Minister of the Federation

COMPLAINTS LAID BEFORE
MAGISTRATES ALLEGING
CRIMINAL MISCONDUCT ON
THE PART OF POLICE OFFICERS


    7. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law (i) what is the procedure adopted by Magistrates when a complaint is laid before them alleging criminal misconduct on the part of named and/or unnamed police officers; and (ii) between 1st June, 1959, and

Column: 706

31st March, 1962, what is (a) the number of such complaints made, (b) the number of such complaints referred by the Magistrates to the police for investigation, (c) the average length of time between the date of the request by the Magistrate to the police for investigation and the date of reply by the police to the Magistrate, and (d) the number of summonses and/or warrants issued by the Magistrates on such complaints.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will break it up into parts. [Interruption] The first part -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not know whether the Minister is threatening us with a long statement. If he is, then perhaps he can make a ministerial statement at the end of Question time.

    Mr Byrne: I shall make the statement brief.

    Mr Speaker: Yes, it should be short. Mr Byrne.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first part of the question asked: what is the procedure adopted by Magistrates when a complaint is laid before them alleging criminal misconduct on the part of named and/or unnamed police officers? The answer to this question is as follows.

    The procedure adopted is that laid down in section 133 of the Criminal Procedure Code which the Member for Anson knows quite well. The assistance of the Commissioner of Police sought in the following circumstances:-

    (a) when the identity of the police officer is not known, the Commissioner of Police is required to ascertain it:

    (b) when the allegation in the complaint is so fantastic on the face of it or for other reasons the Magistrate doubts the truth of the matter complained of, the Commissioner of Police is requested to investigate and report on the allegation:

    (c) when the complaint discloses a seizable offence, the Commissioner of Police is asked to explain why the police have not effected an arrest: and

Column: 707



    (d) when the complaint discloses a seizable offence for which the sanction of the Deputy Public Prosecutor is required under section 128 of the Criminal Procedure Code, the Commissioner of Police is requested to investigate and obtain the necessary sanction from the Deputy Public Prosecutor.

    Then in the next part of the question, I am asked to state the number of such complaints made between 1st June, 1959, and 31st March, 1962. The answer is 31.

    Then I am asked to state the number of such complaints referred by the Magistrates to the police for investigation. The answer is 19.

    Then I am asked to state the average length of time between the date of the request by the Magistrate to the police for investigation and the date of reply by the police to the Magistrate. The answer is, the average length of time is 18 days.

    Then I am asked to state the number of summonses and/or warrants issued by the Magistrates on such complaints. No warrants were issued; 17 summonses were issued; nine notices were issued; three complaints were withdrawn; one complaint was dismissed and one complaint is still pending.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Minister agree that referring complaints about the police to the police for investigation brings about considerable dilatoriness and has he any suggestions for future legislation on that aspect?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the whole list of names of complainants and matters which were referred for investigation. There were 19 complaints which were referred to the police for investigation. There were 12 complaints which were not referred to the police for investigation. The Magistrate has the power to deal with such complaints if the offence disclosed is a serious offence and needs investigation. In such cases, the Magistrate always refers them to the police for investigation. But where the complaints are trivial, he deals with them himself.

Column: 708



    Mr David Marshall: Would the Minister be good enough to direct his mind to the question which seeks to inquire whether the Government is conscious of the frustrating procedure whereby complaints about the police are referred to the police for investigation, and whether they have in mind any legislation to deal with that aspect?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson very well knows what the procedure is. It is true that some complaints are referred to the police for investigation. Before any action can be taken, the investigation papers go to the State Advocate-General's Department, and it is the S.A.G. who has the right under the Constitution to decide whether action should be brought or not. The Member for Anson understands the procedure quite well.

CIGARETTE SMOKING
(Dangers to health)


    8. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he has any information as to the dangers to health of cigarette smoking, and what action does the Government propose to take.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes. This information is contained in a publication entitled "Smoking and Health" which is a report of the Royal College of Physicians of London on smoking in relation to cancer of the lung and other diseases, published by Pitman Medical Publishing Co. Ltd. this year.

    If the Member for Anson is interested, I have the publication here and will let him read it if he likes to. But I would like to mention here that I know that the Member for Anson is a regular pipe smoker and it would be of interest to him if I quote a paragraph from this report which was -

    Mr Speaker: The Minister is here to give information on the question of dangers to health of cigarette smoking and not pipe smoking.

Column: 709



    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker. Sir, this report deals with pipe smoking as well as cigarette smoking.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I cannot allow that, unless the Minister wishes a debate on the question of pipe smoking.

    An hon. Member: Pipe down!

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the following figures of interest for Singapore. Of deaths from lung cancer in 1959, there were 108 deaths. In 1960, there were 131 deaths from lung cancer, and in 1961 there were 138. All deaths from all cancers - in 1959, there were 1,055; in 1960, 1,067; and I have not got the figure for 1961 as it is too early to get them. The total of all deaths in Singapore for 1959 was 10,175; in 1960, 10,210; and in 1961, 10,025. The death rate from lung cancer in Singapore is about ten per cent of the total cancer deaths, and the total of cancer deaths is about one-tenth of all deaths.

    The position in Singapore does not warrant any immediate action. However, my Ministry is watching developments abroad on the investigation and prevention of lung cancer and smoking and will take whatever steps are proved necessary and beneficial.

    Mr David Marshall: In the light of the gravity of the effect of cigarette smoking on health as indicated by the report which the Minister has referred to, would he recommend to the Ministry of Culture that Radio Singapore should not carry advertisements on cigarettes?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it would be advisable if the Member for Anson reads the book I have referred to because it is stated there that it has been proved that advertisements on tobacco do no initiate new smokers. They focus attention on the brands of smokes and they cause smokers to switch their smokes. So I think before he asks these questions, he should first read this book.

MOSQUITO NUISANCE IN
SINGAPORE
(Request for statement)


    9. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he would make a statement as to the mosquito nuisance in Singapore.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to preface my remarks by informing the House that, in my opinion, mosquitoes are not the only nuisance that we have in Singapore.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): What is the other nuisance?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the complaints that we have received over the past three months of this year do not show any apparent increase compared with the corresponding months last year. For example, in March this year there were 62 complaints as compared with 72 in March last year. These complaints are dealt with by the Department which has 16 checkers in the city area and a mobile squad of 14 men in the rural area. As mosquito breeding has often been caused by choked drains - and it is known that hawkers are responsible for this - field officers have on their rounds advised hawkers not to throw rubbish indiscriminately into the drains, and have taken action to clear choked drains.

    Mr David Marshall: Are we to understand that the only criterion of the Ministry of the extent of the nuisance is the number of complaints received? Is there no detailed examination by staff of the areas where mosquitoes breed?

    Mr Byrne: That is regularly done, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the Minister is aware that complaints do not come in anymore, because the people are fed up as conditions have not improved. And can he ascertain whether complaints have not come in because the situation has improved?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the hon. Lady will come to my office I can show her piles of complaints that I have

MALAY AND CHINESE
PUBLICATIONS OF GOVERNMENT
POLICY AS REGARDS
HAWKERS


    10. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he would consider publishing in pamphlet form, in Malay and Chinese, the Government's policy as regards hawkers and the plan of alternative sites being offered.

    Mr Byrne: The Government's hawker policy aims at registering and licensing all hawkers who are not itinerant with a view to accommodating them in suitable pitches. These pitches are being measured out in selected streets by the Hawkers Department. This work has to be done street by street and will take some time. Before the hawkers are re-sited in the newly marked out pitches. The aims and objects of this exercise are clearly explained to them and their co-operation is sought. Most of the hawkers will be permitted to carry on their trade in the places where they are at present. Some may have to be resited. The bases for resiting will be:-

    (1) where it is necessary for health reasons to move a hawker, then he will be given an alternative pitch. For example, if a hawker has a stall over a drain and this hampers the daily cleansing of the drain, then he may be resited elsewhere.

    (2) hawkers may have to be resited if the through passage of normal traffic is obstructed, more especially in the case of an emergency. For example, in the case of a fire a traffic lane must be available for the police and the fire brigade to reach the afflicted area.

    (3) in certain areas whole streets are used by hawkers as markets for specified hours because of the absence of sites for markets in congested areas. For example, in Sago Street and Syed Alwi Road. "No Entry" signs

Column: 712

are put up and general traffic is not permitted during the specified hours. However, a single lane for emergency traffic will still have to be provided.

Hawkers will be grouped in pitches according to the type of trade they carry on. For example, in the case of food hawkers - vegetable hawkers, meat hawkers and fish hawkers - they will be separately grouped in the same street, and all non-food hawkers will be separately grouped together in the same street. Each area must be studied separately.

    No useful purpose can be served in issuing pamphlets in Malay and Chinese. The resiting policy has been explained to the hawkers personally when action is taken to resite them in new pitches street by street. The hawker population will continue to grow and so will the problem increase until a viable basis for industrial expansion is established with merger and a common market, and our problems of unemployment become solvable.

    Mr David Marshall: Does the Minister not consider that it would be fair for the hawkers and helpful to the Government if, in fact, there were pamphlets in the languages which the hawkers could understand showing plans of the sites and the exact policy and period for change, instead of depending on individual inspectors?

    Mr Byrne: I do not agree because there would have to be a pamphlet for each street.

    Mr Rajah: On the question of when a street is to be allocated for sites for hawkers, could the Minister inform the House whether the traffic police are con sulted before a particular street is allocated for such use?

    Mr Byrne: Yes, Mr Speaker, Sir. We have what is known as the Hawkers Advisory Committee. We have Legislative Assemblymen and Assemblywomen, the Commissioner of Police, the Fire Brigade and the P.W.D. Road Department represented on that Committee.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister tell us when is the time to carry out the hawker policy and whether there is any representative of the hawkers in that Committee?

LEGISLATION REQUIRING

AND INCOME BY CIVIL

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, Ministers of the Government have already on their appointment declared a return of all their assets and sources of income to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Parliamentary Secretaries have made similar returns to the Prime Minister. If the House desires, Government can introduce legislation to require all Members of the Assembly to submit a return of their assets and sources of income to the C.P.I.B.

    As regards civil servants, there are already in existence regulations embodied in General Orders 152 and 153 and other relevant General Orders and circulars governing their conduct and personal activities.

GOVERNMENT POLICY ON
BIRTH CERTIFICATES
(Request for statement)


    14. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he will make a statement as to the Government's policy in respect of birth certificates which contain the names of the parents but not of the child and which are supported by Statutory Declarations with photographs identifying the child.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is presumed that the question is in connection with applications for Singapore citizenship and, if so, the position is as follows:

Column: 716



    A birth certificate with the name of the parents but without the name of the child is acceptable as documentary evidence of the child's birth in Singapore if it is supported by a statutory declaration and other corroborative evidence; for example, School Leaving Certificate, Birth Certificates of brothers and sisters or vaccination notice or certificate.

    The statutory declaration, whether or not a photograph of the child is affixed, should be made by a responsible person who is in a position to testify to the child's birth; for example, a parent, grandparent, aunt, uncle, or an elder brother or sister who is at least seven years older than the child in question.

PERSONS DETAINED UNDER CRIMINAL LAW
(TEMPORARY PROVISIONS) ORDINANCE

AS ON 31ST MARCH, 1962



    15. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what was the number of persons detained under the provisions of section 55 of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance as on 31st March, 1962; (b) how many of these persons have been detained for more than 3 years; (c) how many have been detained for more than two years; and (d) how many persons detained under the Ordinance are detained (i) in Changi Gaol, and (ii) in Pulau Senang.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of persons detained under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance as on 31st March, 1962, is 804. Of the 804 under detention, 85 persons have been detained for more than three years; 235 have been detained for more than two years. Of those detained, 375 are in Changi Prison and 423 in Pulau Senang. Up to date, a total of 135 detainees have been released from Pulau Senang.

    Mr David Marshall: Does the Minister envisage the danger that constant companionship and common hardship over a long period of time of detained suspected gangsters may result in coalescing anti-social forces to the detriment of the country?

    Mr David Marshall: May I inquire whether the Minister envisages any danger in having these people together?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, from our experience of Pulau Senang, the result is just the opposite of what the Member for Anson is afraid of.

    Mr David Marshall: May we know the result, Sir, and the policy of the Government in connection with the release of these people or their treatment?

    Mr Speaker: That is a different question.

GOVERNMENT'S POLICY ON
DETAINED SUSPECTED SECRET
